results.title: Shape description. Part 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
This film is designed as a sequel to “Shape description part 1” which presented the theory of orthographic projection. In part 2, the step-by-step procedure of constructing a drawing is demonstrated, and reasons for each step are explained.

results.title: Shape description. Part 1
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
The film begins by demonstrating that the only accurate method of telling others exactly how to build an object is to make several drawings showing how the object looks from different points of view. The film then describes orthographic projection, utilising animated diagrams and animated models to provide unusual three-dimensional effects.

results.title: Shape
results.creator_credit: Murray Louis and American Federation of Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Dance”.
The sculptural dynamics of the dancer’s body is the focus of this film. The dancer is revealed as a sculptor who moulds and transforms himself into forms that lend their force to the eloquence of dance.

results.title: Shape
results.creator_credit: Lewis Jacobs and Young America Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Elements of design”.
Discusses shape as one of the basic elements of design, and its function in the art and industry of everyday life. Shows the effects achieved by use of circles, squares, rectangles, triangles, and their various combinations

results.title: Shantiniketan: Abode of Peace
results.creator_credit: M. Bhavnani, Films Division, Government of India, A P Sinha and K Samarth
results.brief_description: In 1901, there was established at Shantiniketan an institution for boys and girls, where education was in close communion with nature. Twenty years later, the institution had grown to such proportions that it came to be recognised as an international university, the Visva-Bharati. This film gives an interesting glimpse of Shantiniketan the “Abode of peace”, the school of international culture, established by the Poet Rabindranath Tagore at Bolpur, not far from Calcutta. Languages, sculpture, painting, embroidery, music, dancing and other fine arts are an integral part of training.

results.title: Shane Warne
results.creator_credit: Stephen Phillips and Australian Cricket Video
results.brief_description: This is the story of Shane Warne’s mercurial career in his own words. Named one of the five greatest cricketers of the 20th century and Australia’s greatest wicket taker in Test cricket, he commentates on footage of most of the highlights of his career so far, including his Test debut against India in 1991/92, the Test match hat-trick, and the 1999 World Cup victory. He also discusses many amusing behind the scenes tales as well as some of his greatest rivals.

results.title: Shane [Edited version]
results.brief_description: An edited version of the feature film directed by George Stevens. Starring Alan Ladd as the mysterious stranger who assists a family of homesteaders, highlighting the mythology of the Wild West and the image of the American hero.

results.title: Shane
results.creator_credit: Tom Manefield, Sandra Richardson, Ian Munro and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”.
Shane identifies himself as ‘dumb’. The film examines some of the perceptions his parents, siblings and peers hold about Shane by showing him at his school and at his home. The interactions in these two settings illustrate some causes and consequences of low self-esteem

results.title: Shall we dance?
results.creator_credit: Pandro S. Berman, RKO Radio Pictures and Mark Sandrich
results.brief_description: Shall we dance? is a lightweight, farcical, and quite delightful story about people who appear to have no serious problems or thoughts. Fred Astaire plays Petrov, a supposedly Russian ballet dancer, and Linda Keene plays a revue dancer. On the liner, “Queen Anne” - bound for New York from Le Havre, they are mistakenly believed to be husband and wife, and consequently many complications arise from this mistaken premise!
